body:
Hi, first of all I wanted to thank you for this great tool. It was long missing a good looking and usable annotation tool. 
I latch-up in this discussion as I'm also trying to adapt doccano to our workflow and I have some comments. 

1. the information for the export should be self explanatory, so the label should be in the output (maybe it was just overlooked?) - you can still keep the internal id, though
2. we should enable custom tokenisation, that means that if my training data is in sync with other part of my machinery it will be guarantee that such synchronization will be maintained.  The tokenisation is also more robust and would allow to ship more information for each token (for example ortogonal features like formatting etc..) 

My proposal is to follow the prodigy format instead. 
```
{
"spans": [{"start": 58, "end": 72, "token_start": 16, "token_end": 25, "label": "label1"}], [...]
"tokens": [{"text": "We", "start": 0, "end": 2, "id": 0}, {"text": " ", "start": 2, "end": 3, "id": 1}] , [...]
"text": "We have measured the [...]"
}
```

the `token_start/token_end` are the index of the tokens while the `start/end` is the positional index in the text. Even if the token are not supplied, whatever tokeniser is used inside doccano should be used to export the data and maintain the consistency.

Lastly having user information would be additionally great if we want to compute IAA measures from the exported data ;-) 

Cheers
Luca

My vote is for method 2. 

In addition to containing sufficient information, it would enable doccano to play nicely with other tools and systems. For example, after a little reformatting, annotations from an external system (by a human or by a model) could be imported into doccano. In the context of human-in-the-loop models, this would allow doccano to measure agreement between models and annotators (see #114).
@lfoppiano given that doccano does not currently have any features or support for tokenization, I believe that it should be discussed in a separate issue.

issue.title: Enhance Statistics: Compare Annotators

repository.name: doccano
repository.description: Open source annotation tool for machine learning practitioners.

issue.body:
Some annotations tools (such as [Webanno](https://webanno.github.io/webanno/)) include statistics or graphics to help understand [inter-rater reliability](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inter-rater_reliability).   

## Difficulties of this feature
1. Deciding what graphics/statistics to include or not include
    * balancing act between:
      * graphics/statistics that are useful for everyone
      * large list of graphics/statistics that are useful to some
2. Design 
    * subjective 
    * keeping it simple and user friendly
3. Measuring agreement 
    * measuring agreement is different across different annotation tasks
    * how to measure agreement is difficult and/or subjective for some annotation tasks

A button to download well organized data could help with (1), however, this requires an additional feature.  One solution to (3) is to only allow simple metrics that are common across all annotation tasks.

## Example graphics (document classification)
### Label frequency by annotator 
![Capture](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13628629/54439269-d890e700-470e-11e9-9502-06a5fac58b79.PNG)
### Overall agreement between annotators
![Capture1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13628629/54439270-d9297d80-470e-11e9-8016-e567c059b4a9.PNG)
### Contingency table for two users
![Capture2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13628629/54439271-d9297d80-470e-11e9-9c49-c304c1f18e0e.PNG)

issue.title: Support for custom tokenization

repository.name: doccano
repository.description: Open source annotation tool for machine learning practitioners.

issue.body:
From a previous discussion (#113) I've been asked to open a new issue for this specific feature request. 

The use case is the following, as an independent annotation tool, Doccano is now be able to load pre-annotated data but we should add information about tokenisation. 

This because
 - different tasks might require different tokeniser 
 - different languages might be tokenised in several ways 

Therefore to avoid being lock-in with a particular tool and make doccano able to be plugged in any workflow. 
My training data is in sync with other part of my machinery it will be guarantee that such synchronization will be maintained. 

The tokenisation is also more robust and would allow to ship (without necessarly support) more information for each token (for example orthogonal features like formatting etc..)

My proposal is to follow the prodigy format (although I choose that just for simplicity - also the main elements can be called with any name):

```
{
"spans": [{"start": 58, "end": 72, "token_start": 16, "token_end": 25, "label": "label1"}], [...]
"tokens": [{"text": "We", "start": 0, "end": 2, "id": 0}, {"text": " ", "start": 2, "end": 3, "id": 1}] , [...]
"text": "We have measured the [...]"
}
```
- `spans` refer to the list of annotations, 
- `start/end` refer to the offset in the text, while 
- `token_start/token_end` to the index of the tokens.
- tokens `id`  can be any type, maybe string or long are better?

If a user upload plain text to be annotated, doccano can always output it's own tokenisation to export the data and maintain the consistency.
As mentioned before, attached to the `spans` there can be also `user` information but also formatting, and other information that doccano can happily ignore - they must kept and send out in the output)

issue.title: In doccano exported data, only outputs label ids rather than label name? How can we use it for training?

labels.name: duplicate

repository.name: doccano
repository.description: Open source annotation tool for machine learning practitioners.

issue.title: Enhancement/Alignment for import data format and export data format

repository.name: doccano
repository.description: Open source annotation tool for machine learning practitioners.

issue.body:
Currently, the annotated file exported from doccano cannot be imported back into doccano for further validation or annotation because of a misalignment in the import and export formats described here (https://github.com/chakki-works/doccano/issues/113). 

This PR addresses this by adding a new export option that allows the users to export the annotated file with text labels that allows for this to be re-imported into doccano. The feature preview is shown below:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9581213/58054818-a6d23d00-7b10-11e9-86f5-0753ad415900.png)

The original export functionality is maintained as it contains user details for each annotation that is used in inter-annotator analyses.

issue.body:
Currently, the annotated file exported from doccano cannot be imported back into doccano for further validation or annotation because of a misalignment in the import and export formats described here (https://github.com/chakki-works/doccano/issues/113). 

This PR addresses this by adding a new export option that allows the users to export the annotated file with text labels that allows for this to be re-imported into doccano. The feature preview is shown below:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9581213/58054818-a6d23d00-7b10-11e9-86f5-0753ad415900.png)

The original export functionality is maintained as it contains user details for each annotation that is used in inter-annotator analyses.

body: Given that https://github.com/chakki-works/doccano/pull/217 has been merged, can this issue be closed?
